item.title: Surprising examples of Markov chains
item.description: One of the classes that I’m taking this semester is on stochastic processes. Stochastic processes are sequences of random variables $X_1, X_2, ..., X_n$, where \(n\) represents a specific moment in time.1 One way to understand what stochastic process refers to is to break it down into each word. If something is stochastic, it means that it is possible to describe that thing with a probability distribution, to model it. A process occurs over time. Putting those together, you get a sequence of events that are time-dependent, where each event can be ↩︎
